reviewText: "The Ghosts of Versailles," with music by John Corigliano and libretto by William M. Hoffman, was given its world premiere by the Metropolitan Opera, and this is the 1992 telecast of that very production. It featured a large cast, headed by Teresa Stratas, Hkan Hagegrd, Gino Quilico, Marilyn Horne, Graham Clark, and Renée Fleming, and was a magnificent achievement.Hoffman's text is brilliant, and while Corigliano's score is a pastiche, it is an impressive one. He imitates styles from that of Mozart (to boring effect) to the twentieth-century avant-garde (to thrilling effect). It's also rather lengthy: It surprises one that composers and playwrights continue to score such expansive evenings while their audiences' attention-spans grow ever briefer. Previously, Colin Graham's productions at the Met included a very prosaic "La traviata" (1981), so this astonishing staging may come as a surprise. It is endlessly inventive, and takes full advantage of the company's theatrical possibilities.Stratas is extraordinary as the misunderstood Marie Antoinette, giving her all in a controlled, gripping performance. She is the cynosure of the production. Hagegrd sings the role of Beaumarchais gloriously, and Quilico is the ideal Figaro, oozing with charm and athletic magnetism. Horne gives, as might be expected from her, a bravura performance as the exotic Samira. Clark is truly malevolent as the horrible Bégearss (and gives us a morsel of the evil that was the French Revolution), and gives a complete characterization. Fleming, as the Countess Almaviva, is heard here before she turned every score into "jazz," and makes us regret what might have been possible in her career.Several of the other roles are particularly well-cast, especially Tracy Dahl, and Ara Berberian who is heard (not seen) as the Pasha, and Dean Badolato who is seen (not heard) as his Page. Finally, the handsome tenor, Neil Rosenshein, is wonderful as Léon, the illegitimate son of the Countess and Cherubino!

reviewText: John Corigliano has created an excellent "American" opera using props from the past.  His music is excellent, and the libretto is well put together.  The principles, especially Ms Stratas, all fulfill their roles with grace and ease.  This opera should be in the collection of any one interested in 20th century music/opera.

reviewText: The DVD contains a beautiful record of the Metropolitan Opera's world premier production ofGhosts of Versailles. When the opera was first performed the production was a "must see" ticket in New York and the house was filled. That said, this "comic" opera is probably not a classic and while there are some wonderful parts and music, I found it lagging. Conclusion: it is a matter of taste. If you have the spare dollars, and want to view the production, in an excellent recording of it, by all means purchase it.

reviewText: I only had vague remembrances of this opera from the original PBS broadcast. But, I had no recollection of how good this opera was and how good the performances were. The show is full of energy, beautiful visuals, and great singing. It is Renée Fleming's first show at the Met which makes it interesting for many. Lots of humor. And, one of the funniest moments on opera video of Marilyn Horne. It's worth owning just for that sequence. What a great addition to a home library of opera videos. Thanks to the Met for releasing this. Why isn't it done more and why hasn't the Met done it again? It belongs in the repertory. Buy this opera. You will not be disappointed.

reviewText: I'm not a great opera fan but this opera is SO special that I find I can't come up with the words to properly laud it.  I found it originally on a Laserdisc that I treasured even as my laser player moaned and banged and finally died.  I did manage to get the opera transferred to DVD but the quality of both sound and picture was lacking.  All along I scoured Amazon and other sites for an official version of the DVD but nothing until the 40 year Met collection but who could afford that even if you wanted all the other operas?  Finally, VOILA!!!  It is out and it is fantastic!!  Teresa Stratas is mesmerizing as Marie Antoinette who cannot accept her death;  Marilyn Horne with a mind boggling guest appearance and on and on for every performer.  I have long been a fan of John Corigliano
